attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
·       A physical inventory count was carried out on April 8 2025, to verify the accuracy of stock records by matching actual inventory quantities against the figures recorded in the SAP system. Additionally, the count served to assess the effectiveness of internal controls over inventory management.

·       The physical stock count revealed the following discrepancies:

Ø  Bread stock showed a shortfall of 7 Loaves,

Ø  Packing material had  a shortfall of 21 pieces,

Ø  White flour had a surplus of +1.96 kgs,

Ø  Utto experienced a variance of +1kgs,

Ø  Other material items had minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the findings:

Implications:

·       The small variances identified, such as the shortfall in bread stock (7 loaves) and packing materials (21 pieces), suggest that while internal controls are largely effective, there are still minor gaps in inventory handling or documentation that could accumulate over time if not addressed.

The low level of discrepancies also reflects that the branch’s inventory control procedures are functioning well overall, with only minimal variances from expected figures.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management is recommended to continue applying the current inventory management procedures that have proven effective in minimizing discrepancies.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To eliminate or minimize inventory variances identified during physical stock counts and strengthen internal controls around inventory management.

Issues Identified:

  • Bread stock showed a shortfall of 7 loaves.

  • Packing material (poly bags) had a shortfall of 21 pieces.

  • Minor variances observed in white flour and Utto stock.

Root Causes:

  • Possible lapses in stock handling and documentation during dispatch, receiving or production.

  • Potential human errors in recording stock movements.

  • Lack of real-time reconciliation between SAP entries and physical stock movement.

Action Plan:

value:
·       The existing controls are functioning effectively.

We will maintain these measures while exploring opportunities for further improvement to minimize the minor variances observed
We will maintain the good controls

·       In the prior Audit, dated 4th March 2025,the following variances were noted:

ü  Bread stock had a shortfall of -62 Pieces,

ü  Polybags had -13 pieces,

ü  Black Crates had variance of +117,

Utto -0.33 Litres.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread Weights
attributes.description:
·       A spot check on April 11, 2025, assessed the weight of packed bread before dispatch to ensure compliance with weight standards.

·       The findings revealed inconsistencies across different bread varieties, with cases of significant overweight bread recorded.

Ø  Incidence of Underweight Bread: There were very few underweight cases recorded i.e. 600g BW: 7% underweight & 800g CT: 3% underweight.

Ø  Overweight Bread: Most varieties had a high percentage of overweight samples, particularly: 1.5Kg CT all samples were overweight, 600g CT: 87% overweight & 200g ML: 79% overweight.

Implications:

·       The presence of underweight bread in the market potentially subject the company to fines, penalties, or legal action from regulatory bodies.

·       Delivering underweight products can result in customer dissatisfaction, damaging the brand’s reputation and potentially leading to loss of market share.

A high percentage of overweight loaves across several varieties indicates possible overuse of raw materials. This reduces cost efficiency and increases production costs without adding proportional revenue, affecting profit margins
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should increase the frequency of random spot checks to ensure consistent adherence to weight standards across all bread varieties.

Branch management should reinforce the role of production supervisors in closely monitoring weight consistency throughout the baking and cooling processes, especially for varieties previously flagged with issues.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure consistent compliance with bread weight standards, minimize both underweight and overweight products, and enhance cost efficiency in production.

Issues Identified:

  • Instances of underweight bread (7% underweight in 600g BW, 3% underweight in 800g CT).

  • High incidence of overweight bread across several varieties (1.5Kg CT: 100% overweight, 600g CT: 87% overweight, 200g ML: 79% overweight).

  • Potential cost inefficiencies due to overuse of raw materials.

Root Causes:

  • Inconsistent supervision during the dough weighing, proofing, baking and cooling stages.

  • Lack of regular spot checks or calibration of weighing equipment.

  • Variability in dough handling and cooling processes (overcooling observed in 800g CT).

Action Plan:

value:
·       I will increase the frequency of random spot checks to ensure consistent weight compliance.

·       We will also engage with supervisors to reinforce their role in monitoring weight standards.

The issue of overcooling in the 800g CT variety was due to a lapse in supervisory follow-up, and I will ensure this oversight is addressed moving forward.
·       Will ensure production procedures are adhered to always and increase spot checks on dough weights.

·       In the prior audit dated 4th March 2025, it was noted that Underweights in packed breads were as follows;    

ü  400g CTW -1.3%,

ü  600g Ct White-8%,

ü  200 g Minibread-4%.
Previous

attributes.title: Bread damages Percentage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We reviewed the damages for the period from March 9, 2025, to April 8, 2025, to assess whether there were any instances of damages exceeding the established standard limits of 0.2% of total production for production-related damages and 0.5% of total sales for market-related damages.

·       Production damages accounted for 0.22% of total production, exceeding the standard limit by 0.17%, with a cost implication of Ksh 4,124.9,

·       Market damages reached 0.42% of total sales, below the allowable limit of 0.5%

·       The findings were as detailed below:

Implications

·       The production damage rate slightly exceeds the acceptable threshold indicating inefficiencies in the production process that could lead to avoidable losses.

Damage Sent to Ingredient Department.

·        An analysis was carried out on damages sent to the ingredient department between 9 March, 2025, and 8 April, 2025. The objective was to confirm the accuracy of damage records at the branch and to ensure that the actual weighed quantities matched the expected figures.

·       Our findings revealed a variance of -9.78 kg, equivalent to 24.45 fewer pieces than expected, indicating a shortfall in the quantity of damages sent to the ingredient store, as detailed below.

Implication

The expected damages at the branch were tallying with the actual damages weighed only a slight variance of 9.78 kgs explained to be a weight loss of the damages.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should conduct a focused review of the depanning section to identify specific process inefficiencies or equipment issues contributing to bread damages in order to rectify and ensure damages are within acceptable range.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To reduce production-related and market-related bread damages to within the company's set Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), improving operational efficiency and minimizing financial losses.

Issues Identified:

  • Production damages were 0.22% of total production (slightly above the KPI of 0.20%).

  • Market damages were 0.42% of total sales (within the KPI limit of 0.50%).

  • A slight shortfall (9.78 kg) was noted in damages reconciled with the ingredient department.

  • Contributing factors included worn-out baking tins, operational inefficiencies, and minor losses during depanning.

Root Causes:

  • Equipment deterioration, particularly worn-out 400g tins.

  • Operational inefficiencies during depanning and handling.

  • Minor discrepancies in record-keeping and weighing of damaged loaves.

  • Possible human errors during handling and transfer of damages to the ingredient store.

Action Plan:

value:
·       We plan to review the production process, particularly the depanning section, where operational challenges have been observed.

·       Notably, there is a shortage of 400g tins, many of which are worn out and due for replacement

·       The issue has been communicated to the relevant department and is currently under consideration

Controls in place for managing market damages are functioning effectively and will be maintained.

·       The variances are minimal but we will try to ensure the KPI are achieved,

Most of the damages are for 400GMS sandwich due to the status of the tins which are to be replaced.

·       During the prior audit dated 4th March 2025, it was found that;        

ü  Production bread damages were averaging at 0.33% of the production.

Market damages stood at 0.26% of the sales.
Previous

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
·       A detailed review of the mixing charts and summary reports was carried out over a 31-day period, from March 9 to April 8, 2025, to assess whether raw material usage was consistent with the approved Bill of Materials (BOM) and whether production targets were achieved.

·       The purpose of this evaluation was to analyze both shift-level and consolidated mixing chart records, with a specific emphasis on the branch’s Utto oil consumption, average production yield and any occurrences of remixes, as outlined below.

·       Below are summary of the findings:

ü  Utto consumption stood at 100%.

ü  Average yield was 191.88 loaves per bag.

ü  Average production was 65.42 bags per day representing 58.15% of the set target of 112.5 bags.

ü  There we no cases remixes for the reviewed period.

·       The table below shows a summarised findings of the mixing chart analysis.

Findings

·       Analysis revealed a slight overproduction in relation to market demand.

·       Although production levels closely aligned with market needs, the average daily production of 65.42 bags slightly exceeded the average daily sales demand of 64.49 bags, indicating a marginal surplus in daily output possibly accounting for possible fluctuations or unexpected increases in orders as shown in the analysis below:

Implications:

The branch is operating significantly below capacity, which could impact overall efficiency and profitability if not aligned with a strategic scaling plan
attributes.recommendation:
·       Branch management should establish and strictly follow a preventive maintenance plan for critical equipment like the mixer to reduce unplanned downtime and maintain consistent production flow.

While the current demand-based production approach is effective, accurate sales forecasting is essential to avoid unmet customer needs and minimize the risk of unsold bread going to damages.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To enhance production planning, optimize raw material usage, improve production efficiency and ensure production aligns closely with market demand.

Issues Identified:

  • Production target achievement was 58.15%, indicating significant underutilization of capacity.

  • Utto consumption was appropriate (1:1 ratio with production), and no remixes were recorded.

  • Average production (65.42 bags/day) slightly exceeded average sales demand (64.49 bags/day), leading to a small surplus.

Root Causes:

  • Sales fluctuations not accurately forecasted.

  • Mixer machine breakdowns causing disruptions.

  • Occasional manual adjustments to production based on perceived, not forecasted, market demand.

Action Plan:

value:
·       We experienced a mixer machine breakdown, which resulted in two production shifts being not utilized.

·       The issue was resolved but it still impacted the overall achievement of production targets.

Additionally, two other shifts were intentionally cut due to low sales, as production was adjusted to align with current market demand.
The capacity isn’t optimised because of low sales. We are only producing as per market demand.

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       A production efficiency review was conducted over a 31-day period from March 9 to April 8, 2025, to evaluate if the hired production staff met the set efficiency target of 4.50 bags per worker.

·       The actual efficiency achieved was 4.51 bags per worker, which is marginally above the target.

·       The branch operated with one fewer production worker than expected, resulting in a cost saving of Ksh 1,086.60.

·       This indicates that workforce utilization was optimized during the period. A summary of the analysis is shown below;

Implications:

·       Meeting the efficiency shows that existing controls and workforce management practices are effective.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The current staffing and production monitoring processes are effective and should be maintained as the standard.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To maintain and further improve production efficiency above the set Key Performance Indicator (KPI) of 4.5 bags per production worker, ensuring optimal workforce utilization and cost-effectiveness.

Issues Identified:

  • Actual production efficiency was 4.51 bags per production worker, slightly above the KPI.

  • Branch operated with one fewer production worker, saving costs.

  • No major issues, but continuous improvement is necessary to sustain and improve performance.

Root Causes for Potential Risks:

  • Occasional mechanical breakdowns (e.g., mixer) may risk future efficiency.

  • Production alignment with market demand, if not monitored closely, could cause underutilization or overstraining of staff.

Action Plan:

value: The controls in place are generally effective, we shall maintain them with further improvements as might be required.
We will maintain and even aim at increasing the efficiencies

·       In the prior audit;

Production efficiency was 4.54 Bags per production worker.
Previous

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
·       Packing efficiency was assessed over a 31-day period from March 9 to April 8, 2025 to determine if the standard of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

·       The actual performance recorded was 97.15 crates per slicer, slightly exceeding the set target.

·       All 266 hired packers were fully utilized, aligning perfectly with the required staffing levels.

·       There was no overstaffing or understaffing, resulting in no extra labour costs.

·       The table below illustrates the findings;-

Implications:

The team met and slightly surpassed the efficiency target, demonstrating commendable performance and effective resource utilization.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should continue with the current staffing levels and operational procedures as they have proven effective in achieving the required efficiency.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To sustain and improve the achieved packing efficiency, ensure optimal utilization of packing staff and maintain minimal operational disruptions.

Issues Identified:

  • Actual packing efficiency was 97.15 crates per slicer, slightly above the KPI of 97 crates per slicer.

  • No cases of overstaffing or understaffing were reported.

  • Minor downtime due to a temporary packing machine issue (resolved promptly).

Root Causes for Potential Risks:

  • Equipment downtime (even brief) could threaten sustained efficiency.

  • Lack of preventive maintenance might risk future packing machine reliability.

  • Potential complacency over time without active monitoring and motivation.

Action Plan:

value:
·       We will continue to maintain the existing controls in the packing section and implement improvements where necessary.

Although there was a temporary issue with the packing machine, it was resolved promptly.
The team have always surpassed the targets which is recommendable and we will ensure the trend is maintained
In the prior audit, the finding revealed that the average slicing efficiency was 95.26 crates per slicer.
Previous

attributes.title: Mini shop
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was carried out at the mini shop on April 9 2025, to verify that operations aligned with established controls and procedures.

·       The audit specifically reviewed stock movement, sales reconciliation and Mpesa transaction accuracy.

·       The reconciliation process showed that Mpesa till records matched the expected sales, confirming that sales are being properly recorded and tracked.

·       The variance observed was attributed to Mpesa transaction charges.

·       Overall, both cash at hand and Mpesa balances aligned with calculated sales revenue, indicating effective controls. The table below illustrates the findings.

Implications:

The reconciliation of sales and payment records indicates that standards required are being maintained at the mini shop.
attributes.recommendation: ·       The current controls in the mini shop are working effectively and should be sustained, with improvements implemented where necessary.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To strengthen sales recording accuracy, safeguard cash and Mpesa transactions and maintain effective stock controls in the mini-shop.

Issues Identified:

  • Sales reconciliations were accurate with minimal variances.

  • Variances mainly related to Mpesa transaction charges.

  • Cash and stock balances were well accounted for.

  • Controls are effective but need to be sustained and slightly strengthened to prevent future risks.

Root Causes for Potential Risks:

  • Lack of clear, documented adjustment procedures for Mpesa charges during reconciliation.

  • Human error risks in recording cash and stock movements.

  • Potential for future complacency if monitoring is not consistently enforced.

Action Plan:

value: ·       The controls at the minishop are functioning effectively and shall be maintained.
We will maintain the good trend
In prior audit report, minishop attendant accounted for all the bread loaded while there were a variance of -278 attributed transactional charges.

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
·       We conducted an analysis of the generator’s fuel consumption rate for the period ended 31 March 2025 to determine if the Consumption rate was within the set standards.

·       We noted that the Fuel consumption rate for the period was 13.69 Litres/Hour as per tracker system as detailed below while at the book records consumption rate stood at 17.09 Litres/Hour.

Implications:

While the discrepancies in fuel consumption records were minimal, proper calibration remains essential for precise reconciliation.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should maintain the existing controls and ensure proper calibration is carried out to enable accurate reconciliation between the two records.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To ensure accurate recording, efficient fuel utilization and effective monitoring of the generator’s operation to avoid discrepancies and unnecessary costs.

Issues Identified:

  • Minimal discrepancies noted between book records (17.09 L/hr) and tracker system records (13.69 L/hr).

  • Generator consumption was within acceptable operational standards.

  • Need for better calibration and synchronization between manual and tracker records to avoid future variances.

Root Causes for Potential Risks:

  • Possible lapses in manual record-keeping accuracy.

  • Calibration issues with either the fuel meters or tracking systems.

  • Infrequent reconciliation of generator operation hours versus fuel consumption.

Action Plan:

value: ·       The generator's consumption was within the set standards.
To maintain the good controls
In the prior audit, the findings revealed that the generator had run for 1.6 hours while it never consumed fuel.
Previous

attributes.title: Mileage Analysis
attributes.description:
·       The audit was carried out to assess the fuel consumption of the branch’s sales vehicles for the period from March 1 to March 31, 2025. However, due to instances of fuel overconsumption observed in certain vehicles, the review was extended to include the period from February 1st to February 28. Further details are provided in Appendix I

·       The main objectives were to evaluate adherence to fuel efficiency standards, identify areas of inefficiency and provide recommendations to enhance fuel utilization and minimize related costs due to non-compliant with the set standards.

Findings

·       For the month of February 2025,the following vehicles had overconsumption as detailed below;

v  KDQ 554Z (Naitiri route) – Overconsumption: 30.81 litres

v  KDQ 549Z (Eldoret route) – Overconsumption: 20.14 litres

v  KDQ 552Z (Malaba route) – Overconsumption: 24.76 litres

·       For the month of March 2025,the following vehicles had overconsumption as detailed below;

v  Naitiri – Vehicle: KDQ 554Z – 2.71 litres over consumed

v  Kitale – Vehicle: KDQ 547Z – 35.33 litres over consumed

v  Bungoma – Vehicle: KDQ 561Z – 7.52 litres over consumed

v  Kakamega – Vehicle: KDQ 548Z – 4.48 litres over consumed

Implications:

·       The overconsumption observed across multiple vehicles indicates lapses in fuel efficiency.

The excess fuel used directly translates into avoidable fuel expenses, impacting the branch's overall cost efficiency
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should strengthen the fuel monitoring process using daily records and controls for fuel issuing to ensure real-time accountability.
attributes.remediation_plan:
To improve fuel efficiency, eliminate fuel overconsumption across delivery vehicles, and strengthen controls around mileage tracking and reporting.

Issues Identified:

  • Several vehicles showed overconsumption beyond standard rates.

  • Vehicles like KDQ 554Z (Naitiri), KDQ 549Z (Eldoret), KDQ 552Z (Malaba), and others exceeded allowed fuel consumption limits in February and March 2025.

  • Some errors attributed to incorrect cumulative mileage recording by branch manager.

Root Causes:

  • Inaccurate recording of mileage and fuel issued.

  • Possible inefficient driving practices or route deviations.

  • Inadequate review and analysis of daily vehicle consumption reports.

  • Lack of corrective action on repeated non-compliance.

Action Plan:

value:
·       This has been noted, and appropriate corrective actions will be taken.

Stricter controls will be implemented to prevent further instances of overconsumption.
The excess fuel consumed will be recovered, most of the errors arouse from wrong cumulative recordings done by the manager.

In the prior audit, it was noted many routes were compliant with standard consumption except for Vehicle supplying KDQ 554Z which over consumed 8.9 litres, KDQ 549Z over consuming 13.45ltrs, KDQ 552Z over consuming 2.43ltrs and KDQ 548Z over consuming 2.29ltrs.
Previous

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
·       A spot check was carried out at the cash office to confirm that the physical cash on hand corresponded with the recorded cash flow balance and to evaluate the adequacy of the current cash handling controls.

·       All amounts were accurately accounted for, as detailed below:

Implications:

The cash verification process confirms that the cash handling controls are functioning well, as the physical cash on hand aligns closely with the recorded balance.
attributes.recommendation: Continue enforcing strict cash handling policies and regular reconciliations to uphold accuracy and accountability.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To maintain full accuracy, accountability, and security in cash handling processes and ensure that cash balances consistently match recorded figures with minimal or no variances.

Issues Identified:

  • Physical cash was closely aligned with book records.

  • A minor variance of +8.84 Ksh was noted.

  • Controls are effective but continuous improvement is needed to eliminate even small variances and prevent potential risks.

Root Causes for Potential Risks:

  • Minor human errors in cash counting or recording.

  • Possible rounding issues during cash flow entries or handling small denominations.

  • Limited secondary verification processes at cash collection points.

Action Plan:

value: ·       Cash controls are effective, and we will continue to maintain them.
We will maintain the good trend
In a previous audit, it was observed that all cash was fully accounted for
Previous

attributes.title: Debtors’ Analysis
attributes.description:
·       An analysis of the debt balances as of April 9, 2025, was conducted to identify any instances of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.

·       The review specifically focused on dormant unsecured accounts and clients with outstanding balances who were consequently not supplied, as detailed in below

Implications:

·       These outstanding debts increase the risk of potential bad debts, limit cash flow and may affect the branch's ability to meet sales targets, especially for clients who are currently not being supplied due to unpaid balances.
attributes.recommendation: Sales representative to follow up on outstanding balances, particularly those related to unsecured and dormant accounts, to mitigate the risk of these amounts escalating into bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Objective:

To improve debt collection efforts, minimize outstanding balances, prevent the escalation of dormant or unsecured debts into bad debts, and sustain healthy cash flow for branch operations.

Issues Identified:

  • Presence of dormant debtor accounts totaling Ksh 341,662.

  • Active customers with balances not being supplied due to unpaid debts totaling Ksh 126,759.

  • Risk of bad debts increasing if follow-up and collection efforts are not strengthened.

Root Causes:

  • Weak follow-up on overdue debts by sales representatives.

  • Lack of structured debt recovery plans for dormant accounts.

  • Supplying customers without consistently enforcing credit control policies in the past.

Action Plan:

value: Sales team are following all outs standing debts.
Will engage the sales rep and his regional to sort out on the outstanding balances.
In previous audit outstanding debts for customers was Kshs.188, 756.00 while for institutions was Kshs.1, 413,511.50.
Previous
